dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, $1.5 trillion in student loan debt? Seriously?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, one point five dollars trillion in student loan debt? Seriously?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: there are over 44 million borrowers who collectively owe $1.5 trillion in student loan debt.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, no, it's, um, it's a huge deal. And that's just, like, one piece of this bigger picture Kolanovic is talking about.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, no, it's, um, it's a huge deal. And that's just, like, one piece of this bigger picture Kolanovic is talking about.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Kolanovic? Isn't this just, uh, another doomsayer? We've heard this stuff since, like, 2008.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Kolanovic? Isn't this just, uh, another doomsayer? We've heard this stuff since, like, two thousand eight.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but he's pointing to some really specific new mechanisms. Like, the whole passive investing thing? And algorithmic trading?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but he's pointing to some really specific new mechanisms. Like, the whole passive investing thing? And algorithmic trading?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Kolanovic identifies two investing trends that may increase stock market pain during large sell-offs: passive investing algorithmic trading

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Passive investing is bad now? I thought that was, um, the smart way to go.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Passive investing is bad now? I thought that was, um, the smart way to go.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, when 90% of daily trading is from these index and quant funds, and they're programmed to sell weakness... it removes individual buyers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, when ninety percent of daily trading is from these index and quant funds, and they're programmed to sell weakness... it removes individual buyers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to Kolanovic, 90% of daily trading in the stock market is from index and quant funds. Quant funds, he writes, are programmed to sell market weakness - rather than analyze fundamental valuation, for example.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, machines sell to other machines. What's the big deal? Just sounds like a faster crash, I guess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, machines sell to other machines. What's the big deal? Just sounds like a faster crash, I guess.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! A faster crash, lightning-fast machine selling, that's the "Great Liquidity Crisis" part. Uh, nobody's left to buy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! A faster crash, lightning-fast machine selling, that's the Great Liquidity Crisis part. Uh, nobody's left to buy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: a precipitous decline in stocks could cause the Great Liquidity Crisis. Severe stock price declines. Lightening fast machine selling.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And the Fed's just gonna, what, buy stocks? Sounds like, I don't know, desperation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the Fed's just gonna, what, buy stocks? Sounds like, I don't know, desperation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: He says they might have to if markets drop 40% or more. And this isn't just theory, it's being, um, debated in Congress.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He says they might have to if markets drop forty percent or more. And this isn't just theory, it's being, um, debated in Congress.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Kolanovic notes that if markets fall by 40% or more, for example, the Federal Reserve may need to take drastic action to prevent a depression. This would mean the Federal Reserve could purchase equities or attempt to stimulate the economy through additional tax cuts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, when's this supposed to happen? Next week? Next year? They're always predicting something.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, when's this supposed to happen? Next week? Next year? They're always predicting something.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Originally, uh, second half of 2019. But then a leaked memo said, like, late first quarter of 2020. Which was, you know, not that long ago.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Originally, uh, second half of twenty nineteen. But then a leaked memo said, like, late first quarter of twenty twenty. Which was, you know, not that long ago.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In an interview with CNBC, Kolanovic said that while it's not possible to predict the timing of the next financial crisis, he doesn't see potential problems until the second half of 2019.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, so we survived it then? Crisis averted. Cool.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, so we survived it then? Crisis averted. Cool.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the mechanisms he's describing, these shifts in market structure, those are still very much in play. Consumer debt hasn't magically disappeared.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the mechanisms he's describing, these shifts in market structure, those are still very much in play. Consumer debt hasn't magically disappeared.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The rise of passive investing and algorithmic trading could create the backdrop for a substantial stock market drop... While the banking system and mortgage market are stronger today compared to the last financial crisis, consumers still hold substantial debt.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, yeah. More debt, more machines. Sounds like just another Tuesday, honestly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, yeah. More debt, more machines. Sounds like just another Tuesday, honestly.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But it means the next time it happens, it could be, um, dramatically different because of these new factors.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it means the next time it happens, it could be, um, dramatically different because of these new factors.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The rise of passive investing and algorithmic trading could create the backdrop for a substantial stock market drop, according to Kolanovic.
